document_info.title: Clinical Appropriateness Guidelines - Musculoskeletal - Joint Surgery (Evidence: pg no: 1, L5-L11)
document_info.payer: Carelon Medical Benefits Management (Evidence: pg no: 1, L10)

procedures.section_title: Total Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L271)
names: Total Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L271)
Total shoulder replacement (Evidence: pg no: 7, L174)
procedures.description: Prosthetic replacement of the humeral head and the glenoid (total arthroplasty) is most commonly performed for joint damage due to osteoarthritis. Total shoulder arthroplasty requires an intact medial glenoid to support the glenoid prosthesis. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L173-L175)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Anticipated level of function should place limited demands on the shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 9, L267)
Deltoid muscle must be intact (Evidence: pg no: 9, L268)
Shoulder joint must be anatomically and structurally suited to receive selected implants (Evidence: pg no: 9, L269-L270)
Limited range of motion or crepitus of the glenohumeral joint on physical examination (Evidence: pg no: 9, L277)
Pain and loss of function of at least 6 months' duration that interferes with daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 9, L278)
Radiographic evidence of destructive degenerative joint disease (Evidence: pg no: 9, L279-L286)
Failure of conservative management of at least 6 weeks' duration (Evidence: pg no: 9, L287-L288)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)
Shoulder resurfacing, including total, hemi, or partial resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 11, L334-L336)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; total shoulder (glenoid and proximal humeral replacement (eg, total shoulder)) (Evidence: pg no: 11, L364)

procedures.notes: Indications include proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation, malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue, and advanced joint disease due to osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, avascular necrosis, or post-traumatic arthritis. (Evidence: pg no: 9, L272-L276)

procedures.section_title: Hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L289)
names: Hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L289)
Shoulder hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 7, L176)
Partial replacement (Evidence: pg no: 7, L176)
procedures.description: Shoulder hemiarthroplasty (partial replacement) may be used to address isolated humeral head pathology (avascular necrosis), some fractures, or as an option for rotator cuff tear arthropathy. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L176-L177)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation (Evidence: pg no: 9, L291)
Malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue (Evidence: pg no: 10, L293)
Advanced joint disease of the shoulder when criteria for total shoulder arthroplasty are met AND at least ONE of the following conditions is present (Evidence: pg no: 10, L294-L295)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty or hemiarthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 11, L363)

procedures.notes: Specific conditions include osteonecrosis of the humeral head without glenoid involvement, advanced joint disease due to rotator cuff tear arthropathy, glenoid bone stock inadequate to support a glenoid prosthesis, and glenohumeral osteoarthritis with irreparable rotator cuff tear. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L296-L299)

procedures.section_title: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L300)
names: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L300)
Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178)
procedures.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Reconstruction after a tumor resection (Evidence: pg no: 10, L302)
Glenohumeral osteoarthritis with irreparable rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 10, L303)
Glenoid bone stock inadequate to support a glenoid prosthesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L304)
Failed hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L305)
Failed total shoulder arthroplasty with non-repairable rotator cuff (Evidence: pg no: 10, L306)
Shoulder fracture that is not repairable or cannot be reconstructed with other techniques (Evidence: pg no: 10, L307)
Deficient rotator cuff with limited ability to actively flex the upper extremity to 90 degrees against gravity (Evidence: pg no: 10, L310-L311)

procedures.notes: Considered medically necessary for ANY of the listed indications when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L301)

procedures.section_title: Revision or Replacement of a Shoulder Prosthesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L312)
names: Revision or Replacement of a Shoulder Prosthesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L312)
Revision of total shoulder arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 11, L365)
procedures.description: Revision or replacement of a shoulder prosthesis is considered medically necessary for ANY of the following conditions when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L313-L314)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Aseptic loosening of one or more prosthetic components confirmed by imaging (Evidence: pg no: 10, L315)
Fracture of one or more components of the prosthesis confirmed by imaging (Evidence: pg no: 10, L316)
Reconstruction after the management of periprosthetic infection confirmed by gram stain and culture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L317)
Instability of the glenoid or humeral components (Evidence: pg no: 10, L318)
Migration of the humeral head (Evidence: pg no: 10, L319)

codes.description: Revision of total shoulder arthroplasty, including allograft when performed; humeral or glenoid component (Evidence: pg no: 11, L365)
Revision of total shoulder arthroplasty, including allograft when performed; humeral and glenoid component (Evidence: pg no: 11, L366)

procedures.notes: All conditions must be associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L314)

procedures.section_title: Diagnostic arthroscopy (Evidence: pg no: 13, L436)
names: Diagnostic arthroscopy (Evidence: pg no: 13, L436)
Diagnostic arthroscopy of the shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 13, L437)
procedures.description: Diagnostic arthroscopy of the shoulder joint is considered medically necessary for synovial biopsy or tissue harvest (chondrocyte), or when the involved joint meets ALL of the following criteria. (Evidence: pg no: 13, L437-L438)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Presence of ONE of the following symptoms: Significant pain and functional limitation, Instability (e.g., giving way, catching, clicking, locking), Limited range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 13, L439-L442)

Presence of ONE of the following physical exam findings: Limited range of motion, Joint swelling, Inconclusive specific diagnostic exam maneuvers, Local muscle weakness or atrophy (Evidence: pg no: 13, L443-L447)
Inconclusive x-ray and/or advanced imaging studies (Evidence: pg no: 14, L448-L449)
Failure of at least 6 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 14, L450)

exclusions: In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., mi-eye 2®) (Evidence: pg no: 14, L452)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, shoulder, diagnostic, with or without synovial biopsy (separate procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 20, L720)

procedures.notes: All arthroscopic procedures of the shoulder are inclusive of diagnostic arthroscopy and manipulation under anesthesia. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L375-L376)

procedures.section_title: Removal of loose body (Evidence: pg no: 14, L453)
names: Removal of loose body (Evidence: pg no: 14, L453)
procedures.description: Removal of loose body is considered medically necessary when BOTH of the following are present. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L454)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Radiographic evidence of acute, post-traumatic, intra-articular foreign body or displaced fracture fragment larger than the size of an arthroscopy cannula (5 mm or larger) (Evidence: pg no: 14, L455-L456)
Shoulder pain associated with grinding, catching, locking, or popping, and exam findings confirm pain with limited range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 14, L457-L458)

exclusions: Removal of loose body for Kellgren-Lawrence grade 4 osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 14, L460)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with removal of loose body or foreign body (Evidence: pg no: 20, L723)

procedures.section_title: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L461)
names: Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 14, L461)
procedures.description: Rotator cuff repair is considered medically necessary for acute full thickness tear, chronic or degenerative full thickness tear, and partial thickness tear when specific criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L465, L478, L493)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: For acute full thickness tear: Traumatic injury within the preceding 3 months with no preexisting shoulder pain (Evidence: pg no: 14, L467-L468)
Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale exacerbated by movement (Evidence: pg no: 14, L469)
Weakness of rotator cuff muscle(s) (Evidence: pg no: 14, L470)

Physical exam demonstrating a positive response to at least ONE of the following tests: Drop arm test, Painful arc test, Full/empty can test, Weakness of external/internal rotation (Evidence: pg no: 14, L471-L475)
Advanced imaging confirms features of an acute full thickness or high-grade partial tear (Evidence: pg no: 14, L476)

exclusions: Treatment of asymptomatic, full thickness rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 16, L535)
Deltoid or rotator cuff paralysis (Evidence: pg no: 16, L536)
Use of xenografts or biologic scaffold for augmentation or bridging reconstruction (Evidence: pg no: 16, L537)
Use of platelet rich plasma or other biologics (Evidence: pg no: 16, L538)
Concomitant subacromial decompression/acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 16, L539)

codes.description: Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; acute (Evidence: pg no: 20, L707)
Repair of ruptured musculotendinous cuff (eg, rotator cuff) open; chronic (Evidence: pg no: 20, L708)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 21, L740)

procedures.notes: For primary rotator cuff repair, adherence to a tobacco cessation program resulting in abstinence from tobacco for at least 6 weeks prior to surgery is strongly recommended. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L462-L463)

procedures.section_title: Revision Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 15, L505)
names: Revision Rotator Cuff Repair (Evidence: pg no: 15, L505)
Revision rotator cuff repair (Evidence: pg no: 15, L508)
procedures.description: Revision rotator cuff repair is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 15, L509)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Documentation of nicotine-free status for at least 6 weeks prior to surgery (Evidence: pg no: 15, L510)
Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale exacerbated by movement (Evidence: pg no: 15, L511)
Weakness of rotator cuff muscle(s) (less than grade 4/5 on manual muscle testing) (Evidence: pg no: 15, L512)
Recent advanced imaging confirms a full thickness tear (Evidence: pg no: 15, L513)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 15, L514)

exclusions: Recent history of a revision surgery (Evidence: pg no: 16, L524)
Rotator cuff arthropathy defined as a combination of arthritis and lack of rotator cuff (Evidence: pg no: 16, L525)
Wheelchair bound and/or assistive device dependent (Evidence: pg no: 16, L531)
procedures.notes: Adherence to a tobacco cessation program resulting in abstinence from tobacco for at least 6 weeks prior to revision surgery is required. (Evidence: pg no: 15, L506-L507)

procedures.section_title: Labrum Repair (Evidence: pg no: 16, L540)
names: Labrum Repair (Evidence: pg no: 16, L540)
Labral tear including superior labral anterior-posterior (SLAP) tears (Evidence: pg no: 16, L541)
procedures.description: Labrum repair is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 16, L542)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale which interferes with age-appropriate activities of daily living (Evidence: pg no: 16, L543)
Symptoms aggravated by heavy lifting, pushing, and overhead motion (Evidence: pg no: 16, L544)

Physical exam demonstrating a positive response to at least ONE of the following tests: O'Brien (active compression) test, Anterior slide test, Biceps load test (I and II), Pain provocation test, Crank test, Jobe relocation test, Forced shoulder abduction and elbow flexion test, Resisted supination external rotation test (Evidence: pg no: 16, L545-L553)
MRI demonstrating a labral tear that is not a Bankart lesion and is consistent with subjective and objective findings (Evidence: pg no: 16, L554-L555)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 16, L556)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; repair of SLAP lesion (Evidence: pg no: 20, L722)

procedures.section_title: Partial claviculectomy (Evidence: pg no: 17, L560)
names: Partial claviculectomy (Evidence: pg no: 17, L560)
Mumford procedure (Evidence: pg no: 17, L560)
procedures.description: Partial claviculectomy (includes Mumford procedure) is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L560-L561)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Pain at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint aggravated by shoulder motion (Evidence: pg no: 17, L562)
Positive cross-arm adduction test (Evidence: pg no: 17, L563)
Tenderness over the acromioclavicular joint (Evidence: pg no: 17, L564)
Imaging findings (x-ray or MRI) consistent with acromioclavicular joint arthritis (Evidence: pg no: 17, L565)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 17, L569)

codes.description: Claviculectomy; partial (Evidence: pg no: 20, L705)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; distal claviculectomy including distal articular surface (Evidence: pg no: 21, L735)

procedures.notes: For acromioclavicular arthritis. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L559)

procedures.section_title: Arthroscopically assisted lysis of adhesions/capsular release (Evidence: pg no: 17, L571)
names: Arthroscopically assisted lysis of adhesions/capsular release (Evidence: pg no: 17, L571)
Capsular release (Evidence: pg no: 20, L702)
procedures.description: Arthroscopically assisted lysis of adhesions/capsular release is considered medically necessary for post-traumatic, post-surgical, or idiopathic stiffness of the shoulder when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L571-L572)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale which interferes with age-appropriate activities of daily living (Evidence: pg no: 17, L573)
Reduced passive range of motion of the affected glenohumeral joint by at least 50% compared to unaffected shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 17, L574-L575)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 17, L576)

codes.description: Capsular contracture release (eg, Sever type procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 20, L702)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; with lysis and resection of adhesions, with or without manipulation (Evidence: pg no: 21, L736)

procedures.notes: For adhesive capsulitis. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L570)

procedures.section_title: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) (Evidence: pg no: 17, L577)
names: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) (Evidence: pg no: 17, L577)
Manipulation under anesthesia, shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 20, L719)
procedures.description: Manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) is considered medically necessary for post-traumatic, post-surgical, or idiopathic stiffness of the shoulder when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L577-L578)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Shoulder pain ≥ 4 on the VAS scale which interferes with age-appropriate activities of daily living (Evidence: pg no: 17, L579)
Reduced passive range of motion of the affected glenohumeral joint by at least 50% compared to unaffected shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 17, L580-L581)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 17, L582)

codes.description: Manipulation under anesthesia, shoulder joint, including application of fixation apparatus (dislocation excluded) (Evidence: pg no: 20, L719)

procedures.notes: All open procedures of the shoulder are inclusive of manipulation under anesthesia. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L377)

procedures.section_title: Capsulorrhaphy (Bankart procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 17, L584)
names: Capsulorrhaphy (Evidence: pg no: 17, L584)
Bankart procedure (Evidence: pg no: 17, L584)
procedures.description: Capsulorrhaphy (Bankart procedure) is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L584-L585)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: History of a shoulder dislocation or recurrent subluxation (Evidence: pg no: 17, L586)
Positive apprehension/relocation test (Evidence: pg no: 17, L587)
Shoulder pain and/or instability which interferes with age-appropriate activities of daily living (Evidence: pg no: 17, L588)

MRI demonstrates at least ONE of the following: Bankart/labral lesion consistent with the clinical instability, Hill-Sachs lesion, Capsular tear, Capsular redundancy with clinical multidirectional instability (Evidence: pg no: 17, L589-L593)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of conservative management (unless history of traumatic dislocation and multiple dislocations during management) (Evidence: pg no: 17, L594-L595)

codes.description: Capsulorrhaphy, anterior; Putti-Platt procedure or Magnuson-type operation (Evidence: pg no: 20, L713)
Capsulorrhaphy, anterior; with labral repair (eg, Bankart procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 20, L714)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; capsulorrhaphy (Evidence: pg no: 20, L721)

procedures.notes: For chronic shoulder instability or laxity. For traumatic instability, early surgery may be considered for patients with large bone defects or patients under age 35. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L583, L597-L598)

procedures.section_title: Subacromial decompression/acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 18, L600)
names: Subacromial decompression/acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 18, L600)
Acromioplasty (Evidence: pg no: 20, L706)
procedures.description: Subacromial decompression/acromioplasty may be considered medically necessary for ANY of the following indications. (Evidence: pg no: 18, L600-L601)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Symptomatic os acromiale (Evidence: pg no: 18, L602)
Malunited fractures of the acromion/proximal humerus resulting in symptomatic mechanical impingement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L603)
Local benign/malignant tumor resulting in symptomatic mechanical impingement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L604)

exclusions: Subacromial decompression/acromioplasty is otherwise considered not medically necessary for all other indications (Evidence: pg no: 18, L605-L606)

codes.description: Acromioplasty or acromionectomy, partial, with or without coracoacromial ligament release (Evidence: pg no: 20, L706)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; decompression of subacromial space with partial acromioplasty, with coracoacromial ligament (i.e., arch) release, when performed (Evidence: pg no: 21, L737-L739)

procedures.notes: For subacromial impingement syndrome. (Evidence: pg no: 18, L599)

procedures.section_title: Synovectomy (Evidence: pg no: 18, L607)
names: Synovectomy (Evidence: pg no: 18, L607)
Partial synovectomy (Evidence: pg no: 18, L611)
Complete synovectomy (Evidence: pg no: 18, L611)
procedures.description: Synovectomy refers to removal of the synovial lining of the joint when it has become symptomatic due to inflammation, irritation, or pathology. Synovectomy may be performed in a single joint compartment (limited) or multiple compartments (extensive). (Evidence: pg no: 18, L608-L610)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Symptomatic (pain, swelling, limited function) synovitis caused by ANY of the following: Synovial plica (partial synovectomy), Inflammatory arthritides (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis), Crystalline arthropathy (e.g., gout, pseudogout), Felty's syndrome, Pigmented villonodular synovitis (PVNS), Synovial hemangioma, Synovial chondromatosis/osteochondromatosis, Hemophilic synovitis or arthropathy, Infection (bacterial or fungal septic arthritis) (Evidence: pg no: 18, L613-L622)
Failure of at least (6) 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 18, L623)

exclusions: Synovectomy performed solely for visualization or approach, traumatic reactive synovitis (Evidence: pg no: 18, L625)

codes.description: Arthrotomy; glenohumeral joint, with synovectomy, with or without biopsy (Evidence: pg no: 20, L703)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; synovectomy, partial (Evidence: pg no: 20, L724)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; synovectomy, complete (Evidence: pg no: 20, L725)

procedures.section_title: Debridement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L626)
names: Debridement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L626)
Limited debridement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L633)
Extensive debridement (Evidence: pg no: 18, L634)
procedures.description: Debridement of discrete structures of the shoulder (e.g., humeral bone, humeral articular cartilage, glenoid bone, glenoid articular cartilage, biceps tendon, biceps anchor complex, labrum, articular capsule, articular side of the rotator cuff, bursal side of the rotator cuff, subacromial bursa, foreign body[ies]) is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 18, L627-L630)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Shoulder pain unresponsive to 12 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 18, L631)
Surgical pathology is confirmed by imaging (Evidence: pg no: 18, L632)
Limited debridement involves 1 or 2 discrete structures (Evidence: pg no: 18, L633)
Extensive debridement involves 3 or more discrete structures (Evidence: pg no: 18, L634)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; debridement, limited, 1 or 2 discrete structures (Evidence: pg no: 20, L726-L730)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; debridement, extensive, 3 or more discrete structures (Evidence: pg no: 21, L731-L734)

procedures.section_title: Biceps tenodesis or tenotomy (Evidence: pg no: 19, L637)
names: Biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 19, L637)
Biceps tenotomy (Evidence: pg no: 19, L637)
Tenodesis of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 20, L711)
procedures.description: Biceps tenodesis or tenotomy is considered medically necessary for shoulder pain when EITHER of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 19, L637-L638)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroscopy and open procedures when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L373-L374)

documentation: Criteria for SLAP tear (Evidence: pg no: 19, L639)
Pain in the front of the shoulder and/or clicking, popping, or catching sensation when using the arm and shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 19, L641-L642)
Clinical exam is consistent with long head of biceps pathology (Evidence: pg no: 19, L643-L645)
MRI findings consistent with biceps tendinopathy (Evidence: pg no: 19, L646)
Failure of at least 12 weeks of supervised conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 19, L647-L648)

codes.description: Tenodesis of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 20, L711)
Resection or transplantation of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 20, L712)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 21, L741)

procedures.notes: For tendinopathy of the long head of the biceps. Requirement is waived if criteria for rotator cuff tear are met. (Evidence: pg no: 19, L636, L648)

procedures.section_title: Primary Total Hip Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 24, L835)
names: Primary Total Hip Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 24, L835)
Total hip arthroplasty (THA) (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746)
Total hip replacement (THR) (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746)
procedures.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
procedures.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)
